content.description: The wall has a slight ledge   at its base which drops off to the right of the start.   Looks for gaps where mortar is missing from the   wall and reddish mortar revealed where some of   the pointing has crumbled. The coping is almost   completely missing from the a section at the top   of this area.   The Wissahickon Schist selected for this part of   the wall is especially jagged for the first half of the   climb. A large, lightly colored rectangular stone is   set back about 2” deeper than its neighbors near   the halfway mark. Following this ledge is a challenging series of distant crimps, zig-zagging a path   up to a sparse, dynamic finish.
content.location: Come out of the north entrance of Cellblock 4 facing the wall. There will be a tall electric street lamp to your left and a moss-covered stone block partially buried in the ground directly across from the start of this climb.

content.description: This crack starts generously at the bottom and   becomes narrower as it goes up before disappearing to liberally applied mortar marking an   especially challenging crux. Use the broken edge   of the mortar as a left side-pull to cross to a high   crimp and work your way through a forgiving final   sequence to the climb’s completion.
content.location: Stand at the northernmost corner of Cellblock 3,   near the entrance to the hospital. Directly north   is a large crack that diminishes as it climbs, fading   away entirely about 4/5ths of the way up the wall.   This is the last big crack on the north wall approaching the guard tower to the east.

climbs.name: Jugovick's Detail
climbs.fa: William Bishie and William Lynch, 4 September, 1927

content.description: Start   below the cavernous opening shaped like a downward-pointing arrow and work your way up the   large crack offering positive, if flakey holds for   the first 2/3 of the wall. At this point the quality   of stone changes dramatically to smoother, more   rectangular blocks with only small crimps for purchase. You will have to work your way to the left of   the crack to move past the crux. Beware of flaking mortar and active bird’s nests in the crack and   be careful when topping out - the jagged concrete   aggregate that forms the wall’s coping will draw   blood.
content.location: This climb is located on the westernmost quarter of the north wall near the kitchen building. Stand facing the wall with the recessed, rusted metal truck scale to your left and the tall rusty gate to your right and you will see a gaping crack which begins about eight feet up from the ground.

content.description: Be careful on the start of the climb to avoid   falling on rotten wood and rusted metal. After the first quarter of the ascent, sloppy   patched mortar makes a challenging second   quarter, with a few choice crimps pulling you   through to the cruxy third quarter. You will   have to traverse to the right of the initial   crack to reach a series of good foot holds   and a single high crimp for the top out.
content.location: Walk northeast in the baseball diamond until   the information kiosk is to your right and the   Big Graph sculpture is to your left. Facing   the north wall you will see a series of rotting   wooden benches in various states of ruin.   The second from the farthest to the right is   in front of a large low crack in the wall: that   is the start of this climb.

content.description: Since the climb begins over a bench, be careful   choosing foot and hand holds for the first few   moves. About 1/3 of the way up the route is the   crux — an especially smooth section that requires   a high left foot and potentially dynamic reach to a   good positive horizontal shelf. Match hands here   before proceeding to the final sequence surrounded by scraggly vegetation but with a clean series   of holds. Use a recessed stone to the right of the   route’s trajectory for a final solid foot before topping out.
content.location: Exit the central structure between Cellblock 3 and   4 into the baseball diamond. Walking north from   the backstop, look for the metal chain-link fence   extension (built to stop fly-balls from going over)   on the top of the wall and find the biggest crack   below it, just to the left of center of the fence.   Follow the crack down to the route’s start, located conveniently behind the left of the two modern   benches at the base of the wall, which can be used   to step up and start the climb.

content.description: Five routes located along the north wall
